reported third-quarter 2016 earnings of $1.15 cents a share, topping the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.00 cents by 15.0%.KLA has agreed to be acquired by Lam Research (LRCX) in a cash and stock deal worth $5.08 billion. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to earnings and cash flow in the first twelve months following the closure. The companies expect to realize $250 million in annual ongoing pre-tax cost synergies within 1.5-2 years and $600 million by 2020.The merger of these two companies creates an equipment powerhouse with a huge range of products, customer breadth and scale. The increased integration and efficiency of operations could also help the combined entity drive further extension of Moore's Law.Shareholders of both companies approved the merger in Feb 2016.A quick look at the numbers-KLA reported revenues of $712.4 million, flat sequentially and down 3.5% year over year.Products generated 74% of total revenue, up 14.6% sequentially and 4.7% year over year. Services revenue comprised the remaining 26%, down 0.4% sequentially and up 4.9% year over year.Wafer Inspection was the biggest contributor to revenue with a 45% share (up 16.8% sequentially and 3.2% year over year); followed by Global Services & Support with 27% (down 7.2% sequentially but up 2.0% year over year); Patterning was next with 23% (down 20.1% sequentially and 21.4% year over year); and Other 4% (up 75.1% and 21.4% year over year)The biggest contributor by geography was North America, which accounted for 23% of revenue. This was followed by Taiwan (21%), Japan (20%), Korea (12%), China 10%, Other Asia 9% and and Europe & Israel 5%.KLA's gross margin expanded 99 basis points (bps) sequentially and 460 bps year over year to 61.6%.Operating expenses of $199.0 million were down 2.5% sequentially, 8.9% from a year ago. The operating margin expanded 180 bps sequentially and 624 bps from last year to 33.7%.The pro forma net income was $179.3 million, or 25.2% of sales compared to $161.8 million, or 22.8% in the December 2015 quarter and $137.4 million, or 18.6% in the March quarter of last year. Including one-time restructuring and acquisition-related charges as well as merger-related cost on a tax-adjusted basis, the GAAP net income was $175.8 million ($1.12 a share) compared to $152.2 million ($0.98 a share) in the previous quarter and $131.6 million ($0.81 a share) in the year-ago quarter.KLA ended with a cash and short term investments balance of $2.24 billion, down $115.0 million from the previous quarter. During the quarter, the company generated $111.5 million of cash from operations, spending $9.0 million on capital expenses and $82.1 million on dividends. The company didn't repurchase any shares.While uncertainties about the timing of capital equipment purchases remain for the leading provider of process control equipment, its acquisition by Lam Research is a positive for investors.Particularly because of the expected increase in be 3D NAND deployments this year and Lam's strength in the area, which can lead to synergies. FinFET transition at foundries also remains a positive.KLA shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Better technology stocks to invest in instead are Silicon Motion  , which has a Zacks Rank #1 (Buy) or Taiwan Semiconductor  , Mellanox  and Advanced Micro Devices  , which carry a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? Much like comedy, investors deliver best when they get the timing right. Source: I'm not saying you need to be a market timer, however. I'm talking about simply knowing how to look at the big picture - the fundamentals - and determine the time to buy into certain sectors.For example, we've heard from numerous sources that global growth, while not declining, isn't growing very fast. Domestically, the U.S. has already lowered its growth estimate for the year and the Federal Reserve's forecast for two rate hikes could crumble, as the market expects just one instance of rate tightening this year.That means slow growth stocks are the way to go. Solid companies that can endure this middling market are the way to go. It doesn't matter what sector they are in, it's simply a matter of how well they are managing to grow when growth is scarce to come by.These are A-rated stocks with great fundamentals that can form the bedrock of your portfolio. 18%It may be hard to believe, with all the turmoil in Asia, but  (  ), the world's largest mobile phone carrier, is up almost 15% year-to-date.That is a strong indicator that not all of Asia is linked to the fortunes of China. Actually, NTT seems more focused on the U.S. market now.It recently bought the Services division from  (  ) - an IT services provider group that delivers infrastructure and cloud services, application services, and business process outsourcing.Basically, NTT is looking to the U.S. cloud for growth. This is a big deal for Japanese companies. Traditionally, outside of media and automotive, the big firms simply focus on their regional and domestic market. Adding this new growth into the mix is likely why the stock is getting attention.This expansion also helps diversify its base. That's a good thing these days as well. 25% (  ) is the power company of South Korea. And it has been around for 116 years, which means it has seen its share of ups and downs - including its  . It was also succeeding when China wasn't the center of the world's attention, but a backward, isolationist Communist power.The point is, KEP is resilient. And after a rough go of it for the Korean economy, KEP is back on a growth track. Nothing spectacular, mind you, but solid and sustainable.It is also involved in markets outside of Korea, and is one of the top builders of nuclear power plants. New nukes are much more reliable than the older models and they can generate massive amounts of power with zero emissions.KEP is either operating or building thermal power plants from the Philippines to Mexico to China and Saudi Arabia. Simply put, it has a growing international market and will also benefit from a renewed Korean economy. 21% (  ) builds testing and measuring equipment for the semiconductor industry as well as the LED and data storage sectors.That means as long as businesses and people are buying devices with chips and chipsets, KLAC will be along for the ride.This is the boring underbelly of technology that we find indispensable. If you want reliability and consistency, which is absolutely essential in tech equipment, you need to make sure it is up and running. The industry has the "five nines," which is basically a system has to be available 99.999% of the time in any given year.KLAC is one of key companies to ensure that the five nines are met.Even as many tech firms have slowed, KLAC has registered a 4% return year-to-date and it has a healthy 2.9% dividend as a cherry on top. 13.5% (  ) has been around for more than 50 years now, and this is likely the first time you have every heard of this 6,000-employee company that operates 90 offices around the world.That's because it's a behind-the-scenes player that builds analytical instruments for a vast array of industrial production processes. From microscopes to MRIs to metallurgy to manufacturing quality control, BRKR has a piece of equipment to help.But the most interesting space right now is its healthcare work. Every aspect of the healthcare sector is concerned about costs. That means testing and analyzing images are key factors in preparing doctors and healthcare professionals for an accurate diagnosis. And BRKR has plenty of products and equipment to help.And it looks like more people are spotting this hidden gem - it's up 18% year to date. 15% (  ) has been around in one form or another for more than 150 years. That includes  . It was the first company in the world to sell what we consider to be a modern handgun - a repeating fire weapon with self-encapsulated rounds.It has certainly seen feast and famine along the way. But it has only been relatively recently that gun control has taken center stage in U.S. politics in a significant way.After President Reagan was nearly killed by a mentally unstable man, both parties started to look at national gun control legislation. But that has picked up in earnest under President Obama.Interesting factoid: SWHC is up more than 800% since Obama took office. Why? Because gun buyers are worried that new legislation will restrict their ability to own one or multiple guns.The current presidential race - as well as a pending Supreme Court nomination - will only increase gun owners anxieties and boost sales.What's more, SWHC sold off in recent months and is now a bargain. 16.5% (  ) is a play on the cashless society. It is basically the middle man between merchants and consumers. The Visa stamp on your debit card means that Visa is providing the bridge for both sides of the transaction.While this isn't very ground-breaking in the U.S., it's the rest of the world where V will see its growth. Even in economic turmoil, emerging-market consumers see the value in having a form of secure cash, perhaps even more so during tough times.V is growing its base in Latin America, Europe, Africa and Asia. Both earnings and revenues were up for the first quarter, but the problem is growing consumer spending right along with the brand. This spend problem led V to readjust forward guidance for 2016 earnings down to between 7% and 8% on a constant currency basis.The best thing about that is, V is now a bargain. Even Goldman Sachs' analyst is still bullish on Visa over the long term. Get in while V is on sale. 14%Named after the goddess of victory,  (  ) was certainly named appropriately. It has been one of the most reliable winners in the stock market for decades.And the amazing thing is, it has remained nimble and can pivot to take advantage of a market opportunity unlike many companies its size. And for all the  (  ) is, Nike has 10 times the market capitalization.When you're looking for a bedrock stock, it's NKE that fits the bill, not UA. While UA has been growing rapidly, it has a current price-earnings of 60. It's going to be tough to keep that alive as global growth slows. NKE on the other hand, has a P/E less than half of UA's. A much better choice for a less predictable future.NKE recently rearranged its top-level management, which has shaken up some investors, but NKE has proven time and again it knows what it's doing.Get it while nobody's looking.The post  appeared first on  .The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

reported third quarter fiscal 2016 non-GAAP earnings of $1.18 per share, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 8 cents. Earnings decreased 25.0% sequentially and 16.1% year over year.This Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) company has an average positive earnings surprise of 6.84% over the trailing four quarters.Revenues of $1.31 billion decreased 7.8% sequentially and 5.7% year over year. Revenues lagged the Zacks Consensus Estimate by approximately $0.04 billion.Region-wise, Taiwan contributed 27% to third quarter revenues (down 19.7% from the prior quarter), Japan added 13% (down 45.5%), China contributed 15% (down 18.7%) and Korea brought in 27% (down 65.9%).The U.S. accounted for 7% of the revenues (down 7.8%), Southeast Asia brought in 7% (up 22.9%) while Europe contributed the remaining 4% (up 22.9%).Total system shipments were roughly $1.45 billion during the quarter, up 12.3% from $1.29 billion reported last quarter.Geographically, Taiwan accounted for 19% of the shipments (down from 38% in the previous quarter), Japan 12% (down from 21%), China 27% (up from 9%), Korea 25% (up from 15%), the U.S. 6% (down from 8%), Southeast Asia 8% (up from 5 %); and Europe 3% (down from 4%).Non-GAAP gross profit was $592.5 million, or 45.1% of revenues, a decrease of 39 basis points (bps) sequentially and 44 bps year over year.Total operating expenses were $350.2 million, down 0.5% sequentially. Operating margin was 18.4%, a decrease of 235 bps from the prior quarter and 145 bps from last year.Non-GAAP net income was $202.8 million (15.4% of sales) compared with $270.3 million (19.0%) last quarter and $244.9 million (17.6%) in the year-ago quarter.Exiting fiscal third quarter 2016, cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments, and restricted cash and investment balances were $4.8 billion, compared with $4.7 billion at the end of second quarter.Capital expenditures amounted to $46.0 million. The company paid $47.5 million of cash dividends to stockholders during the Mar 2016 quarter.Lam Research provided guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016.On a non-GAAP basis, the company expects revenues of approximately $1.525 billion (+/- $75 million). Shipments are projected to be roughly $1.575 billion (+/- $75 million). Gross margin is predicted to be around 46.0% (+/-1%), while operating margin is likely to be about 22.0% (+/-1%). Earnings per share are projected to be $1.63 (+/- 10 cents) on a share count of nearly 173 million. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.47 per share, so guidance was stronger than expected.Lam Research delivered mixed fiscal third quarter 2016 results with earnings outperforming our estimates but revenues lagging behind.So far, 2016 has been pretty good for the company as it continues to see strong success in the areas of device architecture, process flow and technology inflections.In the quarter just ended, Lam delivered revenues and shipments above the midpoints of the guidance. Gross margin, operating income and non-GAAP EPS were above the high-end of the guidance range.Lam Research has high hopes from KLA-Tencor Corporation  which it has acquired recently. Management expects that the combined company will contribute significantly toward sustainable growth, generating cash and creating value.Going forward, in 2016, the company sees increased adoption rates of 3D NAND technology, FinFETs and multi-patterning. It is likely to continue as the market leader in dielectric etch as Flex F and G Series dielectrics have been extremely successful products thus far. The company anticipates strong demand for leading-edge silicon in the enterprise market, driven by the long-term move to the cloud, storage and competition applications.However, concerns persist in the form of volatility and lower growth expectations globally, with slow but steady improvement in some developed markets balancing the weakness in certain emerging economies.The company believes that its strong position, combined with its commitment to customers and value-enhancing collaborations will help drive performance over the next several years.Other stocks worth considering in the technology sector are ASML Holding NV  and FEI Company  each carrying a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? KLA-Tencor Corp. will pay its quarterly dividend of $0.52 on 3/1/16, Intersil Corp. will pay its quarterly dividend of $0.12 on 2/26/16, and Jabil Circuit, Inc. will pay its quarterly dividend of $0.08 on 3/1/16. We're in a stock picker's market these days. Certainly, there are some sectors to avoid, but many stocks are doing far better than their earnings and the current economic forecast can support.Stock picking is crucial here. For example, buying tech stocks is a dicey game because the U.S. dollar is so strong that any sales outside the U.S. are going to be hurt when that revenue is converted back into dollars.The best approach at this point is to be choosy, looking to companies that will do well in a slow-growth climate, are domestically focused and are committed to their market.I have found seven A-rated stocks for the second quarter that will continue to grow well into 2016. Some throw off a bit of dividend and others don't. But they are all focused and ready for what's coming. (  ) is a company that builds testing and measuring equipment for the semiconductor industry, as well as the LED and data storage sectors.This certainly isn't sexy, but it's essential. Which is why KLAC has been around since 1997, working will all the industry leaders and establishing a strong industry foothold from the days before the dotcom boom. Its roots go back to the mid-'70s when KLA and Tencor were launched.That means KLAC has a strong foundation and has stood the test of time in a highly dynamic and competitive industry.Its new moves into LED and data storage reflect its ability to see ahead and steer to that course.The stock is up nearly 50% in the past six months, while still offering a nearly 3% dividend yield. There' plenty of gas left in this stock's tank. (  ) is Japan's largest mobile phone carrier. And in case you forgot, Japan boasts the third-largest national economy in the world.We don't hear too much about Japan in the news because China is now the big Asian country the talking heads smack their gums about, and it seems they can't manage to keep two competing ideas in their heads, or at least present them to their audiences.So much the better for us. It means we can buy in without having to worry about prices getting bid up as the herd comes in.For years, most of Asia analysis has been China focused, first on its growth, then on its lack of growth. But Japan has been chugging along and many Japanese companies are expanding beyond their national borders. Japanese firms own major U.S. whiskey brands as well as big insurers.But it has all flew under the radar. For example, did you know this major telecom is up 40%-plus in the past year? Can you imagine if a major U.S. carrier had those kind of returns? There would be a stampede into the stock. (  ) is the beneficiary of one ineluctable trend: the growing and shifting demand for healthcare services in the U.S.AHS provides staffing, recruitment and management services for healthcare companies and their facilities.Starting in San Diego 30 years ago, AHS has become a national force as it has been steadily acquiring local and regional players along the way.Now that the Affordable Care Act is law, big healthcare corporations and hospitals and private practices have to adjust their practices to maximize productivity. AHS allows them to do that by increasing their flexibility in hiring.AHS' released its latest earning in mid-February, illustrating why this stock is so attractive: Even in this sluggish economy, AHS posted a 44% earnings increase from the same quarter a year ago. Gross profit was up 56% and it blew the doors off of Wall Street's revenue expectations. (  ) sells skincare, beauty and lifestyle products both directly to consumers through e-commerce and through suppliers. It has operations in the U.S., China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and some parts of Europe.Part of the allure has been its foothold in Asia, where NHTC products are growing in demand thanks to the expanding middle class. These once small luxuries are now becoming the norm for many women in China, in particular. Buying higher quality products is also part of this trend.While China may be sluggish, Japan and South Korea are doing well, so NHTC doesn't live or die by mainland China.Even after a big selloff in January, the stock is up 75% for the past 12 months. The selloff has given it lots of headroom moving into 2016. (  ) is the power utility for South Korea, one of the main economic growth engines in Asia.While it is closely linked to the fate of its massive neighbor, China, South Korea is on a growth track from last year. It's expecting to see 3.1% GDP growth in 2016 vs. 2.6% in 2015. That's a good sign.Also in 2015, there was an outbreak of the Middle East Respiratory System virus, which kept people at home, afraid to venture out and risk infection.MERS is now behind the economy and there's a good chance the Korean central bank will lower interest rates this year to stimulate the economy. That's good for business and consumers. And that's good for KEP. (  ) is one of the leading handgun and firearms manufacturers in the U.S.One thing is certain, when politicians start talking about tightening gun control laws, gun sales go through the roof.And now that we're in the final stretch of the presidential election cycle (aka, the silly season), the gun control rhetoric is flying. It's no wonder SWHC rallied 17% just in February. It also helped that the company reported strong earnings for the quarter.The stock has come off its recent highs, but that's to be expected - SWHC has risen more than 100% in the past 12 months. This small pullback is a good chance to get in before the next leg up. (  ) celebrates it 150th year in business this year.What started as a small door and sash company out of St. Louis has become a national manufacturer and distributor of doors, millwork, building materials and wood products.It has 27 distribution centers that serve commercial homebuilders and contractors in 41 states.HBP only sports a $93 million market cap, but it certainly makes up in experience what it lacks in size. When you have been able to maintain a successful company in a highly competitive and volatile industry for 150 years, you're doing a lot of things right.HBP is up almost 30% in the past 12 months, and as the U.S. economy improves, so will HBP's prospects.The post  appeared first on  .The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

reported second-quarter fiscal 2016 non-GAAP earnings of $1.57 per share, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate by a good 15 cents. Earnings decreased 13.7% sequentially but increased 31.9% year over year.This Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) company has a solid earnings surprise history and an average positive earnings surprise of 5.76% for the trailing four quarters.Revenues of $1.43 billion decreased 10.9% sequentially but increased 15.7% year over year. Revenues also beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.41 billion.Region-wise, Taiwan contributed 31% to second-quarter revenues (down 1.4% from the prior quarter), Japan added 22% (up 8.9%), China contributed 17% (down 5.3%) and Korea brought in 15% (down 21.4%).The U.S. accounted for 7% of the revenues (down 30.7% from the previous quarter), Southeast Asia brought in 5% (down 44.3%) while Europe contributed the remaining 3% (down 33.2%).Total system shipments were roughly $1.29 billion during the quarter, down 18% from $1.58 billion reported last quarter.Geographically, Taiwan accounted for 38% of the shipments (up from 26% in the previous quarter), Japan 21% (up from 17%), China 9% (down from 25%), Korea 15% (up from 13%), the U.S. 8% (flat sequentially), Southeast Asia 5% (down from 8%); and Europe 4% (up from 3%).Non-GAAP gross profit was $648.4 million, or 45.5% of revenues, a decrease of 101 basis points (bps) sequentially.Total operating expenses were $352.1 million, down 3.2% sequentially. Operating margin was 20.8%, a decrease of 299 bps from the prior quarter.Non-GAAP net income was $270.3 million (19% of sales) compared with $313.0 million last quarter.Exiting fiscal second-quarter 2016, cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments, and restricted cash and investment balances were $4.7 billion, compared with $4.5 billion at the end of first quarter.Capital expenditures amounted to $28.0 million. The company paid $48.0 million of cash dividends to stockholders during the Dec 2015 quarter.Deferred revenues decreased from $517.0 million in the previous quarter to $395.0 million, while deferred profit balances decreased to $261.0 million from $325.0 million in the prior quarter.Lam Research provided guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2016.On a non-GAAP basis, the company expects revenues of approximately $1.30 billion (+/- $75 million). Shipments are projected to be roughly $1.43 billion (+/- $75 million). Gross margin is predicted to be around 44.0% (+/-1%), while operating margin is likely to be about 17.0% (+/-1%). Earnings per share are projected to be $1.07 (+/- 10 cents) on a share count of nearly 172.5 million. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.38 per share for earnings and $1.41 billion for revenues.Lam Research delivered solid fiscal second-quarter 2016 results with both earnings and revenues outperforming our estimates.2015 was a phenomenal year for Lam Research. For the first time in the company's history, it crossed $6.00 in earnings per share, grew shipments by 25% to nearly $6 billion and posted record revenues of $5.9 billion with operating profits expanding at more than 1.5 times the revenues.Going forward, in 2016, the company anticipates volatility and lower growth expectations globally, with slow but steady improvement in some developed markets balancing the weakness in certain emerging economies.However, Lam is highly optimistic about the underlying technology drivers of mobility, with clouds and the Internet of Things providing a foundation for multiyear opportunity for their products and services. The company assumes 3-D non-volatile memory, a new memory technologies adoption, are at tipping points this year leading to an accelerated demand for solid-state memory in 2016.Lam Research expects shipments in the first half of 2016 to exceed the second half of calendar 2015. The company expects shipments in the second half of 2016 to grow from the new first-half baseline.The March quarter is projected to be the weakest in 2016 which, however, will be stronger for Lam than 2015.Subsequent with the results, Lam announced a definitive agreement with KLA-Tencor  to acquire all outstanding shares of the latter in a cash and stock transaction. Also, the deal will create a leading semiconductor capital equipment company, strengthen its performance, hasten innovation and expand market relevance.The company believes that the strong position, combined with its commitment to customers and value-enhancing collaborations will help drive performance over the next several years.A couple of stocks worth considering in the technology sector are Amazon.com. nvestors eyeing a purchase of KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) stock, but tentative about paying the going market price of $65.18/share, might benefit from considering selling puts among the alternative strategies at their disposal. One interesting put contract in particular, is the January 2017 put at the $52.50 strike, which has a bid at the time of this writing of $1.30. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 2.5% return against the $52.50 commitment, or a 2.5% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this the  ).Selling a put does not give an investor access to KLAC's upside potential the way owning shares would, because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. And the person on the other side of the contract would only benefit from exercising at the $52.50 strike if doing so produced a better outcome than selling at the going market price. (  ). So unless KLA-Tencor Corp. sees its shares fall 19.4% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $51.20 per share before broker commissions, subtracting the $1.30 from $52.50), the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 2.5% annualized rate of return.Below is a chart showing the trailing twelve month trading history for KLA-Tencor Corp., and highlighting in green where the $52.50 strike is located relative to that history:The chart above, and the stock's historical volatility, can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the January 2017 put at the $52.50 strike for the 2.5% annualized rate of return represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for KLA-Tencor Corp. (considering the last 252 trading day closing values as well as today's price of $65.18) to be 30%. For other put options contract ideas at the various different available expirations, visit the  page of StockOptionsChannel.com.In mid-afternoon trading on Tuesday, the put volume among S&P 500 components was 837,366 contracts, with call volume at 837,366, for a put:call ratio of 0.76 so far for the day, which is above normal compared to the long-term median put:call ratio of .65. In other words, if we look at the number of call buyers and then use the long-term median to project the number of put buyers we'd expect to see, we're actually seeing more put buyers than expected out there in  so far today.  .The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

Chicago, IL - February 03, 2016 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog include  the  (  ),  (  ),  (  ),  (  ) and  (  ).Today, Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.  .U.S. stocks ended an awful January in which investors fled from stocks and invested in safe haven assets, including government bonds and gold. The S&P 500 shed 5.1% in January, its biggest monthly loss since Aug 15. The index also posted its worst January performance since 2009. Not only has it been a harrowing month for the index, investors have had to deal with a continuous slump in  that set the Federal Reserve doubting the health of the global economyAccording to Dow Jones data, it has been the choppiest January for the S&P 500 since 2008. In fact, the S&P 500 had at one point touched a loss of 11% last week before recovering on Bank of Japan's surprise decision to trim a key interest rate into negative territory to still end the month in the red. Additionally, China's economic growth losing momentum, concerns about domestic economic growth and lackluster corporate earnings results dampened investor sentiment.The very same factors are continuing to haunt the stock market in February. Renewed decline in oil prices and signs of sluggish Chinese economic growth compelled the S&P 500 to finish modestly in the red on Monday. Weak U.S. manufacturing data also weighed on investors' confidence.Considering S&P 500's drop from its earlier high it seems that the index is nearing a bear market. The S&P 500 is now 10% off its May 21 record high of 2,130.82 and would be in a bear market if it touches 1,706. The index is already in correction mode. Hence, in this scenario, it would be prudent to invest in top-shelf dividend companies. The recent sell-off has pushed their dividend yields up while the stock market downturn has dragged their share prices down.Let's look at the factors that plagued the markets last month.The slump in global oil prices mostly due to lower demand in an already oversupplied market affected the broader markets. Meanwhile, Iran prepares to add its barrels to a glutted global oil market and Russia continues to pump in oil to boost its ailing economy.On the other hand, jitters about China's weak economy following dismal economic reports raised concerns about the demand for oil. Through the end of January, U.S. crude dropped nearly 12%, which is almost 40% less than what it used to cost a year ago.Moreover, U.S. crude slipped 6.3% during the first trading day of February, under pressure from weak manufacturing data out of China, forecast of a mild weather and doubts about OPEC and non-OPEC countries coming to terms to curtail the rising global supply glut issue.Chinese manufacturing activity contracted at the fastest pace in January since Aug 2012. The purchasing managers' index (PMI) came in at 49.4 in January, lower than the previous month's reading of 49.7. The index contracted for the sixth consecutive month.The Chinese stock market crashed this year, frightening investors worldwide. Chinese stocks tanked around 40% from their June peaks. Chinese banks aren't accepting stocks as warranty for loans, while bank loans in China declined drastically indicating investors' lack of faith in the Chinese markets.China plunged into a bear market territory last month, while other nations throughout the world including United Kingdom, France, Germany and Japan also entered a bear market. This global meltdown is expected to have a significantly negative impact on the U.S. economy.U.S. exporters aren't the only ones to be affected by weak global economic growth; domestic commodity producers are also feeling the pain because of weak global demand and low commodity prices. So far, 207 S&P 500 members have reported fourth-quarter earnings. Total earnings for these companies are down 3.1% from the same period last year on 3.1% lower revenues.Meanwhile, the fourth-quarter GDP growth rate came in at 0.7%, lower than the 2% rate of growth in the third quarter. Lower consumer expenditures, falling exports and a decline in business investment were cited as the main reasons behind this slowdown. Moreover, U.S. manufacturing activity contracted in January for the fourth straight month.The International Monetary Fund also trimmed its 2016 forecast for U.S. economic growth to 2.6% from an earlier forecast of 2.8%. This discouraging financial and economic scenario compelled the Fed to keep the interest rate unchanged in January. The Fed also said that it will monitor global economic developments before deciding on a rate hike in March.History says don't expect stocks to move north in February after they had nose-dived in January. According to Bespoke, since 1939 when the S&P 500 finished below 5% in January, the index suffered an average drop of 1.2% in February. Not only that, it had registered a meager gain of 1.18% in the remaining eleven months of that year.In this scenario, where the stock market is moving downward, it will be wise to invest in dividend paying stocks. These stocks help you to lock in high dividend yield, while share prices fall. The higher the dividend a company pays, more is its value.Dividend stocks pay regular income irrespective of market movements and are ideal for long-term investors. They are also less taxed as compared to interest income, help your portfolio to grow at a compounded rate, protect from earnings manipulation, act as a hedge against inflation, and reflect a solid financial structure and healthy underlying fundamentals.Additionally, such stocks when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) are expected to boost your returns. Chicago, IL - November 04, 2015 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog include  (  ),  (  ),  (  ),  (  ) and  (  ). Today, Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.  .In this 79-month old Bull market, the easy money has already been made. There is nothing quite cheap, unless it's justifiably so.Today, it's all about the next earnings beat story or the latest merger deal or even a brand-new CEO. Welcome to the new Wall Street world of fast markets, fast money and jam-packed trades - where a single piece of news can shoot a stock's price sky high or squash months of gains in a single day.In such precarious times, value, growth or income investing might just fall short of making sustained profits for your portfolio.There is another, time-tested winning strategy: simply bet on the frontrunner stocks that are galloping fast. One of the most successful strategies today is to get in on momentum stocks at the right time.In this market, in a sense, everyone is a momentum trader, scouring for the next hot sector or stock where they can turn a fast profit. This is because momentum stocks have proven to be high fliers in every market setting. But amid all the ups and downs, how will investors distinguish between companies that are just taking a breather before their next leg up from those running on a dead track?More importantly, how shall we separate the ones just running a sprint from those set for a marathon?When we scour for pacesetter stocks that are galloping ahead on strong momentum, we also need to make sure that we don't bet on those which seem off-the-bridle. For instance, small-cap stocks, with their comparatively deeper risk profile, tend to react much more aggressively to events. Thus, pullbacks or turnarounds also happen faster for these companies, and investors may not get out fast enough to avoid getting trapped.Hence, we will focus on large-caps, which are big, established companies in the stock market, and have been around for a while. By virtue of their dominant market position, global footprint and relatively consistent cash flow stream, these companies tend to be more reliable investments.And when these thoroughbreds, most of which are common household names, gain momentum on an upswing, it's safe to assume that there is some strong rationale for the move.Notwithstanding the captivating, time-proven strategy and robust fundamentals, the question remains: When to get in?Here we usher in our new  . The Zacks Momentum Style Score indicates when the timing is best to grab a stock and take advantage of its momentum with the highest probability of success. Back-tested results show that stocks with Style Scores of 'A' or 'B,' when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or #2 (Buy) handily outperform other stocks.A top Momentum Style Score knocks out a lot of the screening process as it takes into account several factors including volume change and performance relative to its peers.Flaunting a Zacks Rank #1 or #2 and a Momentum Style Score of 'A,' the following stocks are marching ahead, full steam, and still appear to have plenty of upside left. Further, these companies, with a market capitalization north of $10 billion, have been seeing positive analyst interest of late. (  )Headquartered in Redwood City, CA, Electronic Arts produces top-selling games and related content and services under the EA brand in various categories, including action-adventure, role playing, racing and first-person shooter games. This company is a leading video game developer that should benefit from not only the continuing rise in new console sales, but the rising trend of mobile gaming.With a market cap of $22.5 billion, EA currently holds a Zacks Rank #1. Over the past month, analysts have become increasingly bullish on the company. The company has seen a sharp spike in the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015, which now stands at $2.67, up from $2.50 a month back. (  )Amazon operates as an online retailer in North America and internationally, through the North America, International and Amazon Web Services segments. The company serves consumers through retail websites, such as  ,  and  , which primarily include merchandise and content purchased for resale from vendors and those offered by third-party sellers.The Seattle-based online retailer recently reported impressive quarterly results, which catapulted shares above its July highs. The company has a market cap of $294.6 billion and currently holds a Zacks Rank #2.Not only does the stock have impressive short-term momentum, it has been witnessing solid activity on the earnings estimate revision front as well. Analysts clearly see good things in the company's future, as the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015 earnings has trended sharply up over the past month, from $1.52 to $1.79 per share, thanks to 8 upward estimate revisions versus just 4 lower. (  )KLA-Tencor designs, manufactures and markets process control and yield management solutions globally. The company recently announced a $10 billion buyout by semiconductor equipment maker Lam Research Corp. The merger of these two companies will likely form an equipment powerhouse with an extensive range of products, customer base and scale.With a market cap of $10.4 billion, the company currently sports a Zacks Rank #2.Analysts have great expectations from the company this year and have been revising 2015 earnings estimates upward over the past month. KLA-Tencor has seen 7 positive revisions over the past 4 weeks, resulting in its fiscal 2016 estimate climbing from $3.34 to $3.56. (  )Tesoro Corporation is one of the largest independent refiners and marketers of petroleum products in the U.S. Its retail-marketing system includes over 2,265 retail stations under the ARCO®, Shell®, Exxon®, Mobil®, USA Gasoline (TM) and Tesoro® brands.Tesoro shares have continued to benefit from the "crack spread" on crude oil. That spread refers to the price of the refining outputs from a barrel of crude and the price of crude. When a barrel is much cheaper than the sum of its parts, refiners do very well. That's why TSO has been on a rampage all year. The company has a market cap of $13.4 billion and currently holds a Zacks Rank #2.Moreover, analysts have become increasingly bullish on the company over the past month, with 6 upward estimate revisions for the company's 2015 earnings. This has led to a sharp spike in the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015, which now stands at $13.86, up from $12.36 a month ago. (  )Texas Instruments Incorporated designs, manufactures and sells semiconductors to electronics designers and manufacturers globally. The chipmaker continues to prudently invest into several high-margin, high-growth areas of the analog and embedded processing markets. This will lead to a gradually increase in its exposure to the industrial and automotive markets, which will boost its operations in the coming times.The company has a market cap of $58.5 billion and currently holds a Zacks Rank #1.Over the past month, analysts have become increasingly bullish on the company, with 18 upward estimate revisions for the company's 2015 earnings. This has led to a sharp spike in the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015, which has increased from $2.56 a month ago stands to $2.71 today.Whether you are looking to beat a hot market or maneuver a period of volatility, these are the right picks for you. love summer and, thankfully, I didn't have to wait a full-year to enjoy my favorite season. The company primarily caters to the North American market but is also keen on securing a larger market share. Like the other solar majors, such as Canadian Solar and SunPower, the company is looking to expand its operations in the Middle East, India, Japan, Australia and South America. Expansion into other geographies would lead to both top-line and margin growth.First Solar is able to develop economically sustainable businesses as it has established its expertise in PV generation solutions as well as in other areas of the solar-value chain, such as project development, EPC capabilities and O&M services. It continues to focus on retaining its competitive edge and aims to further consolidate its position in the market. The company's R&D investments are also proving beneficial.October Return: 18.50%Zacks Rank #2Growth Style Score: AMomentum Style Score: ACitrix Systems beat third-quarter earnings and revenue estimates and issued a bullish view.The cloud-computing company's earnings (excluding special items) came in at 87 cents per share, ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 20 cents and up 53% from the year-ago quarter. Higher-than-expected revenues contributed to the earnings beat.Citrix expects revenues in the range of $3.24 billion to $3.25 billion for 2015. Earnings per share (on an adjusted basis) are projected in the range of $3.85 to $3.90. These projections are much higher than the 2015 Zacks Consensus Estimates of $2.97 per share in earnings on revenues of $3.23 billion.We believe that 2015 is playing out just as it should - easy profits from this 6-year bull market have already been earned and valuations are near fully engorged. Gladly, there is not much fear of a bear market, either.When you add it all up, it says the bull market is still on, only the pace is slowing down to around 5% per year.I agree that doesn't sound quite attractive. But compared with the subdued returns for cash, bonds and precious metals, it is a pretty fair deal.Though early in a bull market there are many hidden gems that can generate substantial returns, it has been six years and nearly every stone has been turned.So don't go looking for a needle in a haystack... it ain't there! Instead look where the sun is shining to make your hay!Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? ooking at the universe of stocks we cover at  , in trading on Thursday, shares of KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) were yielding above the 3% mark based on its quarterly dividend (annualized to $2.08), with the stock changing hands as low as $69.21 on the day. Dividends are particularly important for investors to consider, because historically speaking dividends have provided a considerable share of the stock market's total return. To illustrate, suppose for example you purchased shares of the S&P 500 ETF (  ) back on 12/31/1999 - you would have paid $146.88 per share. Fast forward to 12/31/2012 and each share was worth $142.41 on that date, a decrease of $4.67/share over all those years. But now consider that you collected a whopping $25.98 per share in dividends over the same period, for a positive total return of 23.36%. Even with dividends reinvested, that only amounts to an average annual total return of about 1.6%; so by comparison collecting a yield above 3% would appear considerably attractive if that yield is sustainable. KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) is an S&P 500 company, giving it special status as one of the large-cap companies making up the S&P 500 Index.In general, dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of KLA-Tencor Corp., looking at the history chart for KLAC below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue, and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 3% annual yield.    According to the ETF Finder at ETF Channel, KLAC makes up 3.05% of the iShares PHLX Semiconductor ETF (Symbol: SOXX) which is trading lower by about 0.8% on the day Thursday.The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

ooking today at week-over-week shares outstanding changes among the universe of ETFs covered at  , one standout is the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight Technology ETF (Symbol: RYT) where we have detected an approximate $50.7 million dollar inflow -- that's a 6.8% increase week over week in outstanding units (from 8,100,000 to 8,650,000). Among the largest underlying components of RYT, in trading today SanDisk Corp. (Symbol: SNDK) is off about 0.7%, Autodesk Inc. (Symbol: ADSK) is off about 2.1%, and KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) is up by about 0.3%.  The chart below shows the one year price performance of RYT, versus its 200 day moving average:Looking at the chart above, RYT's low point in its 52 week range is $75.85 per share, with $95.69 as the 52 week high point - that compares with a last trade of $90.98. Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --  . Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks, but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks, but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data, to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased, while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings, so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

This is because momentum stocks have proven to be high fliers in every market setting. But amid all the ups and downs, how will investors distinguish between companies that are just taking a breather before their next leg up from those running on a dead track?More importantly, how shall we separate the ones just running a sprint from those set for a marathon?When we scour for pacesetter stocks that are galloping ahead on strong momentum, we also need to make sure that we don't bet on those which seem off-the-bridle. For instance, small-cap stocks, with their comparatively deeper risk profile, tend to react much more aggressively to events. Thus, pullbacks or turnarounds also happen faster for these companies, and investors may not get out fast enough to avoid getting trapped.Hence, we will focus on large-caps, which are big, established companies in the stock market, and have been around for a while. By virtue of their dominant market position, global footprint and relatively consistent cash flow stream, these companies tend to be more reliable investments.And when these thoroughbreds, most of which are common household names, gain momentum on an upswing, it's safe to assume that there is some strong rationale for the move.Notwithstanding the captivating, time-proven strategy and robust fundamentals, the question remains: When to get in?Here we usher in our new  . The Zacks Momentum Style Score indicates when the timing is best to grab a stock and take advantage of its momentum with the highest probability of success. Back-tested results show that stocks with Style Scores of 'A' or 'B,' when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or #2 (Buy) handily outperform other stocks.A top Momentum Style Score knocks out a lot of the screening process as it takes into account several factors including volume change and performance relative to its peers.Flaunting a Zacks Rank #1 or #2 and a Momentum Style Score of 'A,' the following stocks are marching ahead, full steam, and still appear to have plenty of upside left. Further, these companies, with a market capitalization north of $10 billion, have been seeing positive analyst interest of late.Headquartered in Redwood City, CA, Electronic Arts produces top-selling games and related content and services under the EA brand in various categories, including action-adventure, role playing, racing and first-person shooter games. This company is a leading video game developer that should benefit from not only the continuing rise in new console sales, but the rising trend of mobile gaming.With a market cap of $22.5 billion, EA currently holds a Zacks Rank #1. Over the past month, analysts have become increasingly bullish on the company. The company has seen a sharp spike in the Zacks Consensus Estimate for 2015, which now stands at $2.67, up from $2.50 a month back.Amazon operates as an online retailer in North America and internationally, through the North America, International and Amazon Web Services segments. The company serves consumers through retail websites, such as amazon.com, amazon.ca and amazon.com.mx, which primarily include merchandise and content purchased for resale from vendors and those offered by third-party sellers.The Seattle-based online retailer recently reported impressive quarterly results, which catapulted shares above its July highs. The company has a market cap of $294.6 billion and currently holds a Zacks Rank #2.Not only does the stock have impressive short-term momentum, it has been witnessing solid activity on the earnings estimate revision front as well. That spread refers to the price of the refining outputs from a barrel of crude and the price of crude. When a barrel is much cheaper than the sum of its parts, refiners do very well. That's why TSO has been on a rampage all year. M erger buzz in the semiconductor chip industry might have investors in semiconductor ETFs asking: What's in it for me? A whole lot, say experts. And it's generally a whole lotta good.With top-line growth scarce, chipmakers are finding that volume and scale line the path to higher profits. That's creating the perfect space for mergers and acquisitions, says Angelo Zino, a technology equity analyst for S&P Capital IQ."The best and quickest way to get more volume is via M&A," he said.IShares PHLX Semiconductor (  ) got a boost Wednesday from two mega deals:Western Digital 's (  ) $19 billion bid forSanDisk (  ) andLam Research 's (  ) $10.6 billion merger withKLA (  ).SOXX, which holds 30 stocks, allocates roughly 10% of assets to SanDisk, Lam and KLA combined.It also holdsIntel (INTC), which in June bid forAltera (ALTR) in a $17 billion deal, andAvago Technologies (AVGO), which in May said it would pay $37 billion forBroadcom (BRCM).Chip  should view M&A in the space favorably, Zino said. Stocks of target companies could see potentially significant upside by the time the deal's done.Acquirers tend to gain too.Western Digital, known for its hard-disk drives, could see its SSD-Nand revenue jump to 32% of total revenue from 6% by acquiring flash memory maker SanDisk."It allows them to buy growth," Zino said. "They're buying diversification, they're buying scale."That's something chipmakers are hungry for. They're hurting from slowing demand for PCs and tablets in saturated markets globally, as well as what was until recently a key industry driver."The deceleration of growth is most significant from the smartphone end of things," Zino said.Chip stocks were mauled in the most recent quarter, which saw the broad market lose roughly 6%. SOXX tanked by 11% in Q3 andSPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD), which skews toward smaller caps, 12%. Those steep losses were driven by soft guidance after Q2 results from key players such asTexas Instruments (TXN), said Neena Mishra, director of ETF research for Zacks .Investors also agonized over a slowing macro economy, especially in China, where consumers have a big appetite for electronic devices.But chip ETFs have rallied in October. SOXX is up 8%, XSD 10%. They're high-risk, high-reward bets for  ."In the shorter term, any improvement in the China economic outlook and better-than-expected guidance will continue to support the rally," Mishra said.Signs that the worst may be over are emerging. Texas Instruments soared 12% on the  as the Dallas chipmaker raised its fourth-quarter outlook.And Intel handily beat estimates Oct. 13, with the chip giant reporting solid growth in its data center and Internet of Things units.Mishra, like Zino, views industry consolidation as a positive."In general, mergers can reduce price competition, trim costs and also support development of newer, better technologies in high-growth areas," she explained.The personal computer market is also stabilizing after a tough first half, which should benefit semiconductor companies, Zino said. Plus, the holiday season, a boom time for tech gift-buying, is approaching.The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

ast week,  reported first-quarter fiscal 2016 earnings of 71 cents a share, topping the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 56 cents by 26.8%. The company also announced its merger with semiconductor equipment maker Lam Research Corp.KLA also announced that Lam Research  has agreed to acquire its business in a cash and stock deal worth $5.08 billion. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to earnings and cash flow in the first 12 months following the closure. The companies expect to realize $250 million in annual ongoing pre-tax cost synergies within 1.5 to 2 years and $600 million by 2020. The merger of these two companies creates an equipment powerhouse with a huge range of products, customer breadth and scale. The increased integration and efficiency of operations could also help the combined entity drive further extension of Moore's Law.Let's take a look at the fiscal Q1 numbers:KLA reported revenues of $642.6 million, down 15.0% sequentially and consistent with the year-ago quarter, above the guided range of $595-655 million.Products generated 72% of total revenue, down 20.5% sequentially and 3.3% year over year. Management said that the timing of capital investments at the leading edge and investments for capacity expansion at customers pushed out some product revenue related to the quarter. Services revenue comprised the remaining 28%, up 3.0% sequentially and 9.4% year over year. Services related to post-warranty- period installed systems drove revenue.The biggest contributor by geography was Taiwan, which accounted for 40% of revenue. This was followed by the U.S. (17%), Korea (11%), Japan (11%) and Europe & Israel 6%. Other Asian countries generated 15%. Taiwan (up 8.2% sequentially, 100.7% year over year) and other Asian countries (up 23.2% sequentially, 12.1% year over year) were the most significant geographies in terms of growth.KLA's gross margin expanded 19 basis points (bps) sequentially and 318 bps year over year to 58.7%, better than guided. Positive product mix and lower service charges and costs were almost totally offset by lower volumes and reduced manufacturing efficiencies in the sequential comparison while mix, manufacturing efficiencies and lower service costs were all positive in the year-over-year comparison.Operating expenses of $206.0 million were down 3.9% sequentially, 14.2% from a year ago due to restructuring actions taken earlier in the year. The operating margin shrank 353 bps sequentially but expanded 845 bps from last year to 26.7%.The pro forma net income was $112.2 million, or 17.5% of sales compared to $158.9 million, or 21.0% in the Jun 2015 quarter and $78.7 million, or 12.2% in the Sep quarter of last year. Including one-time restructuring and acquisition-related charges a on a tax-adjusted basis, the GAAP net income was $104.9 million ($0.66 a share) compared to $142.0 million ($0.89 a share) in the previous quarter and $72.2 million ($0.43 a share) in the year-ago quarter.KLA ended with a cash and short term investments balance of $2.27 billion, down $117.7 million from the previous quarter. During the quarter, the company generated $193.8 million of cash from operations, spending $7.3 million on capital expenses, $142.6 million on share repurchases and $101.7 million on dividends.While uncertainties about the timing of capital equipment purchases remain for the leading provider of process control equipment, its acquisition by Lam Research is a positive for investors.The biggest positive this calendar year (the company's fiscal year ends in June) will be 3D NAND deployments and the combination with Lam will further help in that respect. FinFET transition at foundries also remains a positive. Logic is unlikely to get exciting given Intel's (INTC) pushout.KLA shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).Better technology stocks to invest in at the moment are Facebook  and MeetMe  both of which have a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? Sources: Lam Research and KLA-Tencor. Shares of  rose as much as 10.5% on Wednesday and  investors saw their stock make a 25% jump. The two moves share the same catalyst, as Lam is  KLA-Tencor in a blockbuster $10.6 billion deal. Lam's offer of $32 per KLA-Tencor share comes in a combination of cash and stock, so the final price tag will move along with Lam's share prices. The deal has been approved by the boards of both companies, awaiting approval from shareholders and the usual regulatory bodies. If all goes as planned, the merger should close in the summer of 2016.It's rare to see both partners in a freshly announced merger move up on the news, but that's exactly what happened here. The proposed pairing may be structured as a buyout of KLA-Tencor but is more of a merger of equals: The two market caps stand just 14% apart, though Lam's sales are about twice the size of KLA-Tencor's revenue streams.The new company plans to stick with the Lam Research name and ticker, adopting Lam Research CEO Martin Anstice as its first CEO.And with financial debt of just 1.5 times trailing EBITDA profits, Eros compares well with stateside rivals at 3.4 times EBITDA, or , whose ratio stands at 2.8. Lions Gate and CBS are also increasing their effective debt load, while Eros is reducing its own.Both companies also reported quarterly results alongside the merger news. KLA-Tencor saw flat year-over-year revenue growth while earnings jumped 51% higher, easily beating analyst estimates in the process. Lam Research met Wall Street's revenue targets while exceeding earnings targets, reporting 8% higher sales and 21% stronger adjusted earnings.So this was not a move born of desperation, but rather two strong competitors joining forces at a strategically sensible point.The world's biggest tech company forgot to show you something at its recent event, but a few Wall Street analysts and the Fool didn't miss a beat: There's a small company that's powering their brand-new gadgets and the coming revolution in technology. And we think its stock price has nearly unlimited room to run for early in-the-know investors! emiconductor manufacturing is a complicated process, involving multiple steps and sophisticated precision tools, so there are specialized companies providing tools for deposition, etch, lighting, sorting, testing and packaging.Moreover, since it is a very expensive process, a lot of the manufacturing has shifted to lower-cost facilities in Taiwan, Korea and China.End market dynamics and geographic factors have resulted in several challenges and opportunities for semiconductor manufacturers and therefore, also equipment suppliers. So first let's take up the challenges.As outlined in the second part of this series, independent market research from IDC, Gartner and the CEA (U.S.) indicate weakness in tablets and slowdown in smartphone shipments this year. This is the single largest negative for manufacturers right now. The PC market decline is also expected to be greater than earlier expectations, which adds to the pressure.Most mobile devices use chips that are produced by specialized foundries in very large volumes. Moreover, since they have shorter lifecycles, their demand is more or less steady. Because of the very high cost of building, equipping and producing in these foundries, the large volumes are essential for generating profits. So when there is any reduction in demand, the foundries take it on the chin.Other segments involved in manufacturing are memory and logic makers, which are holding up better because of their broader application across markets.The industry is also highly cyclical because when demand enters a growth phase, manufacturing demands increase, which results in higher sales for equipment makers. And when they reduce spending, there is a backlash on equipment providers. Because of the increased discipline, recycling of existing equipment and relatively lower capacity additions by manufacturers in recent years, semiconductor equipment sales have also languished.Technology transitions are helping equipment makers however (although increasing cost pressures for manufacturers). These include:Because of the costs and degree of specialization involved, most of the equipment comes from a handful of suppliers. In fact, according to VLSI Research, the top 10 wafer fab equipment (WFE) suppliers accounted for 82% of the market in 2014. Applied Materials (  ), ASML, Tokyo Electron, Lam Research and KLA-Tencor (  ) remained the top five vendors of wafer fab and semiconductor equipment in 2014. It was a good year for equipment companies with Tokyo Electron and Applied Materials gaining share, KLA remaining strong in process control and Lam Research (  ) leading in ECP.Lam Research is a solid pick this year because its capabilities in deposition, etch, multi-pattering and TSV, and exposure to WFE and 3D NAND segments. The Zacks Rank #1 company has a good history of positive earnings surprises and its estimates for this year and the next are also up.The recent currency devaluation should have been a negative for semi equipment makers, but the fear seems unfounded because there is no abatement in the demand for chips. If anything, Chinese demand for semiconductors continues to increase. Yes, it's true that the Chinese government is trying to develop the domestic industry which can once done affect demand. But for now, any development activity will involve U.S. players.For instance, a Qualcomm (  ) subsidiary, Semiconductor Manufacturing International (SMI), and China Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund Co., Ltd., (CICIIF) are looking to make a joint investment of $280 million in Chinese company SJ Semiconductor Corp to build out 12 inch capabilities slated for mass production next year. The goal is to make a facility of global standards indicating a reliance on U.S. equipment players.Chinese foundry SMI currently has a Zacks Rank #3, but given that it posted triple-digit positive surprises in the last two quarters and its 2015 and 2016 estimates up 40% and 21%, respectively, the stock could be worth tracking.Gartner says that foundries grew 16.1% last year, led by Taiwan Semiconductor (  ), United Microelectronics (  ), Globalfoundries, Samsung and SMI. Ultra mobile devices, wearables and Apple's iPhones, as well as more IDM revenue shift to foundries were the attributed factors driving demand. Intel didn't make the list partly because it doesn't broadly sell foundry services.But Intel (  ) and Samsung are the two largest spenders, followed by TSM. So when Intel and TSM decided to reduce capex for the year, equipment suppliers saw share prices slump. Samsung said little at the time it announced earnings, but is consuming more of its own chips. It has also won more semiconductor business from Apple and looks set to score other wins. Media reports indicate that it will spend $14 billion on equipment this year. TechNavio expects the global foundry segment to grow at a CAGR of 8.4% from 2014 to 2019.The semiconductor industry is made up of 10 sub-sectors within the Technology sector, which is one of the 16 broad Zacks sectors. The following table seeks to explain the position of companies in the semiconductor market in the context of the Zacks Industry Rank.We rank the 264 industries across the 16 Zacks sectors based on the earnings outlook and fundamental strength of the constituent companies in each industry. To learn more visit:  .The outlook for industries positioned #88 or lower is 'Positive,' between #89 and #176 is 'Neutral' and #177 and higher is 'Negative.'As indicated in the table above, the first two semiconductor segments are positive, the next one is neutral, while the rest are negative.The average rank of stocks in each sub-sector is indicated in the last column [Note: Zacks Rank #1 for individual stocks denotes Strong Buy, #2 is Buy, #3 means Hold, #4 Sell and #5 Strong Sell].Practically all of the companies in the broader Technology sector, of which Semiconductors constitute a part, have reported Q2 results. The earnings beat ratio of 2.5% was much better than the S&P 500 average miss of 2.1%, while the revenue beat of 3.0% also bettered the S&P 500, which averaged -3.4%.Total earnings for the sector were up 2.5% year over year (7.4% in 1Q15). Total revenues were up 3.0% from last year (4.9% in Q1).Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? Today, you can download  . Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? ooking at the universe of stocks we cover at  , in trading on Wednesday, shares of KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) were yielding above the 4% mark based on its quarterly dividend (annualized to $2.08), with the stock changing hands as low as $51.55 on the day. Dividends are particularly important for investors to consider, because historically speaking dividends have provided a considerable share of the stock market's total return. To illustrate, suppose for example you purchased shares of the S&P 500 ETF (  ) back on 12/31/1999 - you would have paid $146.88 per share. Fast forward to 12/31/2012 and each share was worth $142.41 on that date, a decrease of $4.67/share over all those years. But now consider that you collected a whopping $25.98 per share in dividends over the same period, for a positive total return of 23.36%. Even with dividends reinvested, that only amounts to an average annual total return of about 1.6%; so by comparison collecting a yield above 4% would appear considerably attractive if that yield is sustainable. KLA-Tencor Corp. (Symbol: KLAC) is an S&P 500 company, giving it special status as one of the large-cap companies making up the S&P 500 Index.In general, dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of KLA-Tencor Corp., looking at the history chart for KLAC below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue, and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 4% annual yield.    According to the ETF Finder at ETF Channel, KLAC makes up 2.55% of the First Trust NASDAQ-100-Technology Sector Index Fund ETF (Symbol: QTEC) which is trading relatively unchanged on the day Wednesday.The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.

reported fourth-quarter 2015 earnings of 99 cents a share, topping the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 91 cents by 8.8%.Management said that spending remains focused on the memory side, particularly 3D NAND, with uncertainties continuing in other areas particularly logic.Intel (INTC) announced earlier that it wasn't expecting to ship 10m chips until 2017, so management statements indicating a 10nm push out for equipment into the first half of 2016 wasn't unexpected (last quarter, 10nm shipments were pushed out to the second half of the year). Intel is a major customer for KLA.Since KLA sells process control equipment that improves efficiency of operations, it is particularly helpful for foundries. Management expects foundries to spend on FinFET as we move through the rest of the year, so this will be a positive for the company.Some time back, KLA started increasing exposure to the memory segment, which is proving to be a good decision in the current environment. The company saw a big jump in orders from this segment.Of course what all this boils down to is that WFE spending is unlikely to play to KLA's strengths this year. Management started the year with the announcement of a 10% reduction in headcount that they said were designed to streamline operations, align product development efforts to changing industry demand and also allow investment in new areas. But earlier in July, they raised the dividend by a couple of cents, so investors wouldn't be disappointed.A quick look at the numbers-KLA reported revenues of $756.3 million, up 2.4% sequentially and 3.0% from the year-ago quarter, above the guided range of $550-750 million and 1just short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate.Products generated 77% of total revenue, up 2.6% sequentially and 1.6% year over year. Services revenue comprised the remaining 23%, up 1.9% sequentially and 7.7% year over year.New orders in the fourth quarter were $672 million, down 2.9% sequentially, 25.2% year over year and better than the guided $550-750 million.Memory accounted for 62% of total orders in the last quarter, up 249.2% sequentially and 81.3% year over year. Foundry was next with a 33% share, down 58.4% sequentially and 67.4% from last year. Logic brought in a mere 5% of orders, declining 31.6% and 62.6%, respectively from the previous and year-ago quarters.Shipments were up sequentially and year over year to $739 million although not as strong as expected. Management attributed the weakness to the push out of a high-ASP reticle inspection system, adjustments at a foundry customer moving to a sub 20nm process and an accident at a customer's fab that also pushed out some shipments.Backlog was down 7.7% sequentially and consistent with the year-ago quarter. Backlog excluding the value shipped but not recognized as revenue was also down 7.7% sequentially.KLA's gross margin expanded 155 basis points (bps) sequentially and 264 bps year over year to 58.5%, in the middle of the guided range. Management said that mix was the strongest factor affecting the gross margin in any quarter.Operating expenses of $214.3 million were down 1.8% sequentially, 7.2% from a year ago due to restructuring actions taken earlier in the year. The operating margin expanded 278 bps sequentially and 574 bps from last year to 30.2%.The pro forma net income was $158.9 million, or 21.0% of sales compared to $137.4 million, or 18.6% in the Mar 2015 quarter and $133.2 million, or 18.1% in the Jun quarter of last year. Including one-time restructuring and acquisition-related charges a on a tax-adjusted basis, the GAAP net income was $142.0 million ($0.89 a share) compared to $131.6 million ($0.81 a share) in the previous quarter and $128.7 million ($0.77 a share) in the year-ago quarter.KLA ended with a cash and short term investments balance of $2.34 billion, down $27.0 million from the previous quarter. During the quarter, the company generated $242.4 million of cash from operations, spending $10.3 million on capital expenses, $168.7 million on share repurchases and $82.3 million on dividends.For the first quarter of fiscal 2016, KLA expects orders of $450-650 million and shipments of $610-690 million. Quarterly revenues are expected to be between $595 million and $655 million, gross margin of 56-57% and opex 212 million. The tax rate is expected to be 22% and yielding non-GAAP EPS in the range of $0.46 - $0.66, an extremely wide range and missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $0.90 by a wide margin. The weak guidance is mainly because of increased uncertainties related to the timing of orders and weak demand, which is having an effect on order shipments, revenue and therefore, margins.KLA-Tencor reported a moderate quarter dampened by a very weak guidance. Uncertainties about the timing of capital equipment purchases are weighing on the company's results. The biggest positive this calendar year (the company's fiscal year ends in June) will be 3D NAND deployments by memory makers and FinFET transition at foundries. Logic will remain weak throughout.In this environment, we think management cut headcount at just the right time and also announced a higher dividend to shareholders, which speak of good execution.KLA shares currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold), but considering the weak guidance, we expected estimates to come down, which could push it to a lower rank.Better technology stocks to invest in at the moment are LendingClub  and Healthstream  both of which have a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), or Google  , which has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).Want the latest recommendations from Zacks ? , the leading manufacturer of process control equipment, has announced its decision to hike quarterly dividend by 2 cents to 52 cents per share. This translates into a 4% increase from the prior dividend of 50 cents.The increased dividend will be effective with KLA-Tencor's quarterly dividend to be declared in Aug 2015.The strength of KLA's business model is reflected in its strong cash generation capabilities and commitment to return value to shareholders. We believe that the continued increase in dividends will inspire investors' loyalty through higher returns.KLA's strong balance sheet and cash flows provide financial flexibility required for dividend hikes, share repurchases and strategic acquisitions. During the fiscal third-quarter, the company spent $168.7 million to repurchase shares and $82.3 million on dividends. The cash and short-term investments balance was $2.34 billion, down $27.0 million from the previous quarter. Moreover, KLA generated $242.4 million of cash from operations.We remain encouraged by KLA's strong cash position and ability to service its long-term debts.KLA reported strong fiscal third-quarter results, with both revenues and earnings per share surpassing our expectations. However, the company provided weak fourth-quarter guidance mainly due to increased uncertainties related to the timing of orders and weak demand, which is affecting order shipments, revenues and therefore, margins.In the last quarter, the company also announced its intention to reduce headcount, streamline operations, and align product development efforts with the changing industry demand and invest in newer areas. KLA is expected to release the fiscal fourth-quarter results on Jul 30.Currently, KLA carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).
